EFD advises incorporating periodic reviews of EU fishing policies’ humanitarian impacts, particularly addressing displacement risks seen in Western Saharan and Somali coastal communities.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally agrees the issue's binding oversight mechanisms for fisheries agreements, perfectly aligning with their demand for verifiable development impact assessments in partner nations like the Comoros.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the parliamentary insistence on immediate discard reduction frameworks, seeing this as critical to transforming temporary measures into permanent ecosystem safeguards as urgently advocated.  

GREEN_EFA fully supports the requirement for multilateral implementation reviews, recognizing this as essential to ensure future agreements mandate local employment quotas and port infrastructure investments in coastal states.  

GREEN_EFA endorses the cross-border enforcement provisions as fully realizing their vision of fisheries partnerships that prioritize stock sustainability over short-term fleet profitability.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s institutional collaboration mandate, viewing it as foundational to achieving the systemic transparency reforms they have championed since 2005.

ALDE strongly accepts the amendments enabling small inshore vessels to operate safely with tangle nets, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to preserving coastal livelihoods while protecting cod stocks.  
ALDE approves the pragmatic integration of boarfish catch limits into existing regulations, effectively advancing regional fishery innovation as prioritized in their sustainability agenda.  
ALDE proposes maintaining current co-financing rates rather than increasing them to 75%, emphasizing the proven efficiency of existing frameworks while fully endorsing enhanced control systems.  
ALDE applauds the Comoros agreement’s 10-nautical-mile protection zone for local fishers, perfectly matching their manifesto goals for equitable international partnerships.  
ALDE strongly accepts the issue’s emphasis on scientific cooperation, reinforcing ALDE’s evidence-based approach to sustainable resource management.

SD entirely promotes the issue's alignment with sustainable fisheries governance, perfectly reflecting SD's commitment to inter-institutional collaboration and legal clarity in EU-third country agreements.  
SD highlights the critical need for updated scientific data collection frameworks as essential to fulfilling the issue's goals, aligning with SD's longstanding prioritization of evidence-based resource management.  
SD emphasizes the issue's advancement of equitable economic partnerships through the Comoros fisheries agreement, which aligns perfectly with SD's development-focused approach to global marine resource sharing.  
SD proposes strengthening future protocols by embedding explicit sustainability ceilings for third-country catches to enhance ecological accountability, building on the issue's existing partnership model.  
SD underscores the urgency of resolving institutional coordination gaps in fisheries policy implementation, urging accelerated Council engagement to prevent operational delays in conservation measures.

ECR strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on parliamentary oversight and transparency in international fisheries agreements, aligning perfectly with ECR's longstanding commitment to institutional accountability under the Lisbon Treaty.  
ECR proposes amending Article 5 to include mandatory interim parliamentary briefings during third-country negotiations, ensuring Members can discharge supervisory duties without opposing the regulation’s core objectives.  
ECR applauds the procedural collaboration with national parliaments outlined in the issue, which effectively advances ECR's priority of decentralizing EU decision-making to reflect member-state realities.  
ECR endorses Struan Stevenson’s amendment to limit temporary catch composition rules to 18 months, preventing prolonged unintended consequences while maintaining alignment with conservation goals.  
 ECR underscores the need to formalize Commission reporting timelines in Annex II to address transparency gaps raised by Marek Gróbarczyk, ensuring future negotiations adhere strictly to Treaty obligations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning fisheries, adopting its stance at first reading based on the Committee on Fisheries’ report (A7-0017/2011) and contributions from the Portuguese and Italian legislatures, as well as the European Economic and Social Committee. It called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending to substantially amend or replace it, ensuring parliamentary oversight. The resolution emphasized procedural adherence by instructing the Parliament’s President to formally transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reflecting collaboration across EU institutions and member states while maintaining legislative integrity.

title: Compliance with the rules of the Common Fisheries Policy: REPORT on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 establishing a Community control system for ensuring compliance with the rules of the Common Fisheries Policy
background: The 2009 EU Fisheries Control Regulation required alignment with post-Lisbon Treaty institutional procedures, mandating reclassification of Commission powers into delegated/implementing acts. The European Commission proposed amendments to ensure legal coherence with Treaty Articles 290 and 291. The Parliament will discuss adapting fisheries control rules to Lisbon Treaty governance frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue’s procedural integrity measures, aligning with their commitment to transparent and legally sound fisheries governance under the Common Fisheries Policy.  
EPP urges the Commission to prioritize a comprehensive revision of the Control Regulation, addressing sectoral concerns about fragmented amendments while advancing sustainability goals.  
EPP emphasizes balancing delegated acts with enhanced parliamentary oversight resources to ensure robust implementation without overextending institutional capacities.  
EPP advocates for adaptable regional fisheries frameworks under EU standards, recognizing member states’ unique maritime contexts such as Croatia’s distinct operational realities.  
EPP highlights the necessity of strengthening the European Parliament’s oversight mechanisms through dedicated committee resources to fulfill Treaty obligations effectively.

GREEN_EFA rejects the proposed amendments for fundamentally undermining enforcement mechanisms critical to sustainable fisheries management  
GREEN_EFA opposes weakening the Control Regulation framework that directly conflicts with core principles of ecosystem-based fishing limits  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's failure to maintain Parliament's hard-won budget increases for compliance monitoring and catch data verification  
GREEN_EFA condemns contradictory legislative signals that jeopardize the CFP reform's enforcement capacity  
GREEN_EFA demands rejection of any text revisions permitting reduced inspection standards or delayed implementation timelines

ALDE strongly promotes the updated control regulation as vital for enforcing sustainable fishing practices and eliminating unfair competitive advantages from illegal activities.  
ALDE approves the enhanced funding accessibility in the issue, recognizing its critical role in empowering member states to implement robust monitoring systems aligned with CFP objectives.

SD strongly promotes the issue’s procedural safeguards for legislative transparency, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to institutional accountability under the reformed Common Fisheries Policy.  
SD applauds the Lisbon Treaty adaptation mechanisms, effectively advancing SD’s priority of modernizing control systems to match post-2009 governance frameworks.  
SD endorses integrating advanced monitoring technologies to streamline compliance checks, proposing a minor amendment to prioritize R&D funding for real-time catch reporting tools.  
SD emphasizes the urgency of expediting the Commission’s revised control regulation to enforce the discard ban, ensuring alignment with sustainability targets.  
SD recommends enhancing regional advisory council consultations to address biogeographic specificities, particularly for outermost regions like the Azores.

ECR strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on uniform compliance standards across EU member states, aligning with their commitment to equitable and sustainable fisheries management.  
ECR entirely agrees the procedural focus on legislative transparency, particularly the requirement for Commission accountability in policy revisions, which strengthens trust in EU governance structures.  
ECR highlights the urgency to address Baltic Sea ecosystem degradation, proposing amendments to restrict industrial fishmeal production practices that destabilize cod populations and marine food chains.  
ECR advocates for prioritizing small-scale fisheries in implementation measures, urging safeguards against market dominance by large trawlers to protect traditional fishing communities.

GUE_NGL conditionally upholds the procedural framework but requests fundamental revisions to address centralized policy flaws undermining control effectiveness.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0009) concerning fisheries policy, adopting its first-reading stance as outlined in the Committee on Fisheries’ report (A7-0468/2013). title: Conservation of fishery resources: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 850/98 concerning the conservation of fishery resources through technical measures for the protection of juveniles of marine organisms and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1288/2009

The Parliament will discuss revising conservation rules to strengthen ecosystem-based management and align with updated scientific and operational standards.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the procedural adherence and legislative transparency outlined in the issue, particularly the alignment with Committee on Fisheries recommendations regarding sustainable external fleet operations.  
EPP proposes amending the exclusivity clause provisions to allow temporary EU fleet access in third-country waters during protocol renegotiations while maintaining sustainability commitments.

title: Combating illegal fishing at the global level: REPORT on combating illegal fishing at the global level - the role of the EU
background: Illegal, unreported, and unregulated fishing, linked to biodiversity loss, economic distortion, and food insecurity, persisted despite international agreements and EU regulations. The EU, as a major fisheries market and importer, faced calls to strengthen global governance. The Parliament will discuss the EU’s role in addressing illegal fishing through international cooperation and regulatory frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP supports the issue’s focus on stringent enforcement of IUU regulations and flag-state accountability, aligning with their commitment to sustainable fisheries and marine biodiversity.  
EPP advises expanding DNA-based traceability systems and port state measures while prioritizing technical aid to developing nations through enhanced Fisheries Partnership Agreements.  
EPP suggests harmonizing penalties across Member States to eliminate enforcement disparities and strengthen sanctions against EU operators linked to IUU networks.  
EPP highlights the need to formalize cooperation with major fishing states like Japan and China in RFMOs to address transboundary IUU operations effectively.

EFD proposes amending the issue to classify EU discard practices as institutionalized IUU fishing, demanding alignment with Norway’s full catch retention policies.  
EFD questions the effectiveness of centralized port state measures without first addressing CFP mismanagement that depleted EU stocks through decades of complex rules.

GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the issue’s mandate to withhold EU subsidies from IUU operators, aligning with their commitment to ending public funding of ecologically destructive practices, and proposes enhancing real-time audit mechanisms to prevent loopholes in subsidy enforcement.

GREEN_EFA approves the integration of IUU combat into EU external policies, particularly trade preference suspensions for non-compliant states, as a critical step toward market-state responsibility and global ocean justice.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need to replicate community-led models like Scotland’s conservation credit scheme within CFP reforms, ensuring incentives for legal fishing align with localized stewardship practices.

ALDE strongly accepts the issue’s focus on combating IUU fishing, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to safeguarding SMEs and ensuring equitable market access for legal fisheries operators.  
ALDE approves the emphasis on intra-EU cooperation and proposes enhancing maritime surveillance through a unified European coastguard service, as advocated in the 2008 integrated maritime policy report, to strengthen enforcement coherence.  
ALDE underscores the urgency for the Commission to table concrete proposals on interagency coordination, ensuring operational synergies across member states to dismantle IUU networks.  
ALDE emphasizes the dual necessity of supporting developing nations through partnerships while rigorously enforcing traceability standards within EU markets to protect both global ecosystems and local economies.  
ALDE advocates accelerating the phasing-out of flags of convenience, aligning with the issue’s call for flag-state accountability to eliminate loopholes exploited by IUU operators.

SD strongly sanctions the issue's emphasis on global port state measures and traceability systems, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to eradicating IUU fishing's economic and ecological harm.  
SD endorses the call for DNA-based traceability as critical to protecting law-abiding fishers, proposing enhanced EU funding for rapid implementation in partnership with developing states.  
SD applauds linking IUU fishing to transnational crime frameworks, urging immediate Interpol collaboration to match the issue's urgency on organized crime networks.  
SD highlights the need to address regional gaps like Black Sea governance, suggesting the Commission prioritize dialogue platforms there while fully backing the report's RFMO expansion goals.

ECR advises expanding enforcement responsibilities to all parliamentary committees, not just the European Commission, to ensure cohesive implementation across governance levels.  
ECR recommends balancing stringent EU fisheries requirements with equivalent global enforcement to prevent disproportionate burdens on European fleets while maintaining environmental goals.

GUE_NGL rejects the inclusion of European coastguard proposals as a violation of national sovereignty, fundamentally doubting with their opposition to supranational militarization of fisheries control.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue’s failure to address IUU fishing’s disproportionate impact on EU outermost regions like Réunion and Martinique, overlooking critical aspects of colonial-era resource exploitation patterns.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s reliance on punitive trade sanctions against developing states as inconsistent with their principle of equitable North-South cooperation in fisheries management.  
GUE_NGL disputes the adequacy of DNA traceability systems without binding provisions to dismantle corporate-dominated seafood supply chains that enable IUU laundering.  
GUE_NGL asserts the issue’s market-based labeling schemes contradict their demand for public-sector-led resource governance, failing to address profit-driven overfishing at its core.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns about Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing, which accounts for 11-26 million tonnes annually (15% of global catches), threatening marine biodiversity, food security, and sustainable fisheries. It emphasized the EU’s responsibility as the world’s largest importer of fisheries products to combat IUU through robust enforcement of regulations like the IUU Regulation, Control Regulation, and Fishing Authorisations Regulation, which mandate flag-state accountability, traceability, and sanctions. The resolution called for ending "flags of convenience," enhancing international cooperation via Regional Fisheries Management Organizations (RFMOs), and expanding port state measures to block IUU catches. It urged stricter penalties for offenders, including EU operators, and withholding EU subsidies or aid from vessels engaged in IUU activities. The Parliament stressed the need for transparency, including public registers of IUU offenders, DNA-based traceability systems, and consumer labeling (e.g., Marine Stewardship Council) to ensure legal sourcing. It linked IUU fishing to transnational organized crime, advocating Interpol involvement and alignment with the UN Convention on Transnational Organized Crime. The resolution highlighted support for developing countries through technical aid, Fisheries Partnership Agreements, and trade measures like suspending preferences for non-compliant states. It called for integrating IUU combat into EU external policies, prioritizing ocean governance at the 2012 UN Sustainable Development Summit, and leveraging market-state responsibility to close global IUU trade networks, ensuring coherence between trade, environmental, and development policies.

title: Common fisheries policy: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Common Fisheries Policy
background: The European Union's Common Fisheries Policy faced persistent challenges including overfishing, declining fish stocks, and resource inefficiency, with scientific warnings about unsustainable practices. Institutional frameworks struggled to balance ecological preservation with fishing industry demands. The Parliament will discuss reforming fisheries management to ensure sustainable resource use and long-term sector viability.

GREEN_EFA absolutely upholds leveraging co-decision authority to institutionalise transparency, mirroring their insistence on participatory governance to prevent renewed CFP failures.

ALDE completely advocates the issue's emphasis on protecting small coastal island communities, perfectly aligning with our commitment to preserving unique European maritime heritage and sustainable livelihoods.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the call for standardized EU-wide fisheries control regimes, eliminating regulatory disparities that undermine fair competition and effective enforcement against illegal practices.  
ALDE fully supports the science-driven approach to discard reduction through avoidance incentives and regional solutions, mirroring our manifesto priorities for ecosystem-based fisheries management.

ALDE applauds the issue's recognition of North-East Atlantic mackerel stock urgency, aligning perfectly with our transboundary sustainability agenda.

SD strongly endorses the binding discard ban as a transformative step toward sustainable fisheries, aligning perfectly with SD's ecological stewardship principles and coastal community protection agenda.  
SD completely promotes the Maximum Sustainable Yield framework, recognizing its scientific foundation to rebuild fish stocks while ensuring long-term industry viability across EU waters.  
SD proposes enhancing Article 15 to explicitly prioritize funding for selective fishing gear modernization, addressing concerns about fragile multispecies fisheries through the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for sufficient additional resources in the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for 2014-2020 to enable the EU to fulfill its existing policy priorities, new tasks under the Treaty of Lisbon, and respond to unforeseen challenges, while challenging the Council to identify lower-priority projects if it opposed this approach. The resolution called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments were introduced, ensuring legislative transparency. It reiterated the importance of maintaining EU commitments to competitiveness, sustainability, and inclusivity, underlining the proven European added value of existing priorities.

title: Common organisation of the markets in fishery and aquaculture products: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the common organisation of the markets in fishery and aquaculture products

SD urges strict penalties for illegal fishing practices, particularly labeling fraud, to ensure the issue’s goals are not undermined by non-compliance.

ECR strongly advocates the issue’s mandate for landing sharks with fins naturally attached, aligning perfectly with ECR’s commitment to eradicating wasteful practices and promoting sustainable fisheries.  
ECR approves the closure of regulatory loopholes to end shark finning, emphasizing that this measure effectively advances marine conservation goals while simplifying enforcement.  
ECR highlights the opportunity to enhance utilization of shark byproducts (e.g., meat for animal feed) as a supplementary measure to maximize resource efficiency.  
ECR endorses strict alignment with CFP reform principles, particularly the prioritization of low-impact fisheries and sustainable quota allocation frameworks.  
ECR stresses the necessity of zero derogations to ensure uniform compliance across all EU vessels, reinforcing the issue’s environmental integrity.

GUE_NGL partially advocates the prohibition on shark finning as a necessary measure but requests revisions to Article 3 ensuring compensation for small-scale fishers disproportionately impacted by gear restrictions.  
GUE_NGL underscores the issue’s failure to address historical overexploitation by European fleets in third countries, demanding binding clauses to restrict EU vessels’ access to developing nations’ waters.  
GUE_NGL acknowledges amendments removing discriminatory technical measures against Portuguese fleets yet urges stricter scientific review requirements for future fishing gear regulations.  
GUE_NGL highlights contradictions between the issue’s environmental goals and its silence on export-driven market incentives for shark products, proposing trade restrictions on fin exports.  
GUE_NGL cautions that partnership agreements with third countries risk perpetuating resource extraction models unless amended to mandate local value-added processing quotas.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0798) concerning fisheries and environmental policies under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, specifically Articles 294(2), 43(2), and 294(3). It adopted its first-reading stance, emphasizing the need for sustainable resource management and alignment with environmental goals. The resolution incorporated input from the Committee on Fisheries and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health, and Food Safety (report A7-0295/2012), urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts. It further directed the Parliament’s President to communicate its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring transparency and adherence to legislative procedures.

title: Multiannual plan for the western stock of Atlantic horse mackerel and the fisheries exploiting that stock: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multi-annual plan for the western stock of Atlantic horse mackerel and the fisheries exploiting that stock
background: Following the 2009 European Commission proposal for a multiannual management plan for the western Atlantic horse mackerel stock, delays arose from post-Lisbon Treaty institutional adjustments and debates over aligning scientific assessments with sustainable fishing practices. The Parliament will discuss establishing a long-term regulatory framework to balance stock conservation and fisheries exploitation in EU waters.

stances.stance:
EPP fully accepts the multiannual plan’s harvest control rule as perfectly aligning with sustainable yield objectives under Article 43(2) of the TFEU.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s legal coherence by defending Parliament’s Lisbon Treaty-grounded role in setting fishing opportunities through ordinary legislative procedure.  
EPP proposes strengthening socio-economic protections for artisanal fisheries through Amendment 7’s explicit recognition of historic rights in Zone 8C.  
EPP fully supports maintaining single-stock management integrity while advocating enhanced regional implementation flexibility through Council collaboration.  
EPP perfectly aligns with scientific prioritization by rejecting fragmented TACs and upholding ICES assessments as the basis for multiyear planning.

EFD supports the multi-annual plan's framework for stock management but advises revising Annex I to mandate real-time catch reporting, reducing the discard practices criticized in North Sea fisheries.  
EFD proposes amending Article 6 to include transitional funding for coastal communities impacted by quota systems, addressing the GBP 2.8 billion annual subsidy burden noted in national assessments.  
EFD recommends stricter review intervals in Article 9 to align conservation targets with regional economic viability, preventing further job losses in dependent industries.  
EFD expresses concern that the issue perpetuates centralized CFP governance models, urging explicit provisions for member-state flexibility in fishery recovery strategies.  
EFD advises incorporating discard ban enforcement mechanisms into Chapter III to mitigate ecological damage, referencing the 880,000 tonnes annual waste cited in policy critiques.

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue’s alignment with scientific advice on maintaining unified horse mackerel quotas, rejecting divisive measures that contradict ICES recommendations as outlined in Article 3.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the precautionary exploitation rate cap of 0.3 for anchovy stocks, mirroring their manifesto commitment to ecosystem-based fisheries management in Article 4(2).  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing safety margins in Maximum Sustainable Yield (MSY) targets by designating them as upper limits rather than goals, strengthening the issue’s sustainability framework.  
GREEN_EFA endorses multiannual planning for industry predictability while urging accelerated reforms to discard policies through regionalized decision-making frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA fully aligns with binding TAC reductions when stock thresholds are breached, ensuring the issue operationalizes the precautionary principle as demanded in their 2010 policy agenda.

ALDE strongly upholds the application of the precautionary principle in fisheries management, aligning with their commitment to sustainable resource use and long-term ecological stability as demonstrated by successful stock recovery models.  
ALDE approves the issue’s integration of scientific data collection and improved catch methods, ensuring a balance between marine conservation and the economic viability of fishing communities.  
ALDE recommends maintaining unified Total Allowable Catch allocations to prevent fragmentation risks, safeguarding coherent implementation across managed fisheries.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of increased research funding and streamlined bureaucratic processes to address knowledge gaps and enhance policy effectiveness in sustainable fisheries management.  
ALDE advocates exploring regulated by-catch utilization systems to reduce discards while supporting market demands, aligning economic incentives with conservation goals.

SD strongly upholds the issue's foundation in scientific data for setting fishing quotas, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to evidence-based marine conservation.  
SD applauds the integration of technical measures prohibiting high-grading and protecting Baltic biodiversity as a critical step toward sustainable fisheries management.  
SD urges immediate Council compliance with Parliament’s codecision authority under the Lisbon Treaty, emphasizing procedural integrity in fisheries governance.  
SD proposes amending Article 4 to explicitly recognize coastal horse mackerel fisheries’ distinct operational needs, ensuring socio-economic stability without opposing the plan’s core objectives.  
SD endorses extending the issue’s science-driven framework to future aquaculture regulations, matching their manifesto priorities for ecosystem-balanced production.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning fisheries policy, based on the Commission’s initial proposal (COM(2009)0189) and the implications of the Treaty of Lisbon’s entry into force outlined in the Commission’s communication (COM(2009)0665). It adopted its first-reading stance, emphasizing alignment with Article 43(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which governs common agricultural and fisheries policies. The resolution incorporated the European Economic and Social Committee’s opinion from 17 March 2010 and urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to or replacing the original text. The Parliament directed its President to transmit its formal position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring procedural continuity under Rule 55 of its Rules of Procedure and reflecting the Committee on Fisheries’ recommendations (report A7-0296/2010). The focus remained on maintaining legislative coherence and interinstitutional accountability.

title: Stock of herring distributed to the west of Scotland: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1300/2008 of 18 December 2008 establishing a multi-annual plan for the stock of herring distributed to the west of Scotland and the fisheries exploiting that stock
background: The 2008 multi-annual plan for west Scotland herring stock management required revision under evolving EU governance frameworks, including post-Lisbon Treaty legislative procedures. Institutional disagreements emerged over implementing versus delegated acts for fisheries policy adjustments. The Parliament will discuss amending the regulatory framework to align with Treaty obligations and scientific management practices.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the multiannual management plan's alignment with sustainable yield principles, emphasizing its consistency with EPP's commitment to balancing ecological preservation and fishing industry viability.  
EPP applauds the integration of Regional Advisory Council insights as critical to achieving science-based yet locally informed stock management, reflecting EPP's prioritization of subsidiarity in fisheries governance.  
EPP proposes enhancing discard reduction strategies by advocating progressive, regionally tailored quotas rather than blanket bans, ensuring alignment with practical industry realities while maintaining ecological goals.  
EPP underscores the necessity of maintaining Member State autonomy in fishing rights allocation, opposing market-driven transferable concessions as incompatible with small-scale fleet protections central to EPP's socioeconomic agenda.  
EPP firmly endorses Parliament's codecision role under Lisbon Treaty provisions, demanding Council compliance to uphold institutional parity in fisheries reform negotiations.

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue’s reinforcement of parliamentary oversight under Treaty provisions, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to transparent and ecologically responsible fisheries governance.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the unanimous committee adoption as a critical advancement toward dismantling failed centralized systems, effectively advancing their priority of regionalized stock management for sustainable marine ecosystems.  
GREEN_EFA proposes integrating binding sea-basin cooperation mechanisms into ongoing CFP reforms to operationalize decentralization while preserving the issue’s procedural safeguards.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of prioritizing science-based stock conservation over institutional turf wars, strongly endorsing the report’s alignment with long-term community viability.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need to resolve Treaty of Lisbon ambiguities through participatory reform processes to prevent bureaucratic stagnation in achieving conservation targets.

ALDE strongly promotes the issue's emphasis on stakeholder consultation through the Pelagic RAC and STECF, aligning with their commitment to evidence-based fisheries management.  
ALDE approves the insistence on Treaty of Lisbon co-legislative procedures as crucial for democratic accountability in EU fisheries policy.  
ALDE proposes establishing a structured negotiation procedure between Parliament and Council within six months to resolve interinstitutional disputes about harvest control rules.  
ALDE endorses the focus on minimizing discards through avoidance strategies rather than dead fish landings, matching their sustainability priorities.  
ALDE urges enhanced Council engagement with parliamentary oversight mechanisms to prevent unilateral quota decisions conflicting with multiannual plans.

SD strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on parliamentary oversight through Article 294(2) TFEU, aligning with SD’s commitment to transparent EU decision-making and fisheries sustainability.  
SD approves the integration of delegated acts for adapting fishing mortality rates to scientific findings, ensuring dynamic management of herring stocks while maintaining legislative accountability.  
SD proposes strengthening procedural alignment by urging the Council to fully adopt Treaty of Lisbon provisions on delegated acts, enhancing Parliament’s role in fisheries governance without opposing the core plan.  
SD applauds the issue’s procedural rigor in communicating positions to national parliaments, reflecting SD’s priority of multi-level democratic engagement in environmental policy.  
SD highlights the need to future-proof the plan by explicitly linking stock migration protocols to preemptive scientific review, ensuring continuity in conservation efforts.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s proposal (COM(2011)0760) concerning fisheries policy, adopting its stance at first reading as outlined in the Committee on Fisheries’ report (A7-0145/2012). It emphasized adherence to Treaty provisions, particularly Article 294(2) and Article 43(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which govern legislative procedures. The resolution urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces the proposal, ensuring parliamentary oversight. It also directed its President to formally communicate Parliament’s position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reflecting procedural alignment with the European Economic and Social Committee’s opinion from January 2012. The focus remained on consolidating Parliament’s legislative role and maintaining transparency in the EU decision-making process.

title: Small-scale and artisanal fisheries and CFP reform: REPORT on small-scale coastal fishing, artisanal fishing and the reform of the common fisheries policy
background: The Common Fisheries Policy faced challenges addressing socio-economic vulnerabilities, structural constraints, and data gaps affecting small-scale coastal and artisanal fisheries, particularly in outermost regions, amid calls for sustainable resource management and equitable access. The Parliament will discuss integrating these fisheries into CFP reform, balancing conservation goals with their role in coastal communities' livelihoods and food security.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the rejection of mandatory transferable fishing concessions, aligning with their commitment to protecting small-scale fisheries from economic discrimination, and proposes enhancing accountability through EMFF ex-post conditionality mechanisms.  
EPP approves the issue’s emphasis on modernizing aging fleets for safety and sustainability, advocating for delegated acts to establish clear technical criteria while maintaining capacity ceilings.  
EPP endorses regionally tailored fisheries agreements but suggests strengthening transparency clauses to ensure third-country compliance with international sustainability standards before access fee negotiations.  
EPP aligns with the shark finning ban proposal, recommending additional verification measures to confirm imported fisheries meet EU sustainability benchmarks without undermining domestic fleets.  
EPP strongly accepts increased EMFF funding for coastal communities, emphasizing the need to prioritize projects that integrate youth training and address generational renewal in artisanal fishing sectors.

EFD supports the issue’s emphasis on decentralized fisheries management and rejection of mandatory transferable fishing concessions, aligning with their advocacy for regional autonomy.  
EFD advises enhancing enforcement mechanisms for Mediterranean overfishing, proposing stricter monitoring of stock regeneration efforts as a critical amendment.  
EFD recommends incorporating explicit bans on shark finning practices, including mandatory "fins-attached" landing rules, to strengthen ecological safeguards.  
EFD highlights the need to address market imbalances through sustainability labels but urges clearer definitions to prevent bureaucratic burdens on small-scale operators.  
EFD stresses the importance of EMFF funding prioritization for coastal communities but raises concerns about administrative delays in compensation during biological rest periods.

GREEN_EFA supports the issue’s emphasis on decentralizing fisheries management to address regional specificities, aligning with calls for localized decision-making to reduce discards and improve technical measures.  
GREEN_EFA advises expanding the sustainability label criteria to explicitly prohibit practices like shark finning, ensuring imported products meet stricter ecological standards beyond current EU norms.  
GREEN_EFA endorses modernizing fleets but proposes amending funding priorities to include retrofitting vessels with bycatch reduction technologies, addressing discard-related inefficiencies highlighted in technical debates.  
GREEN_EFA welcomes gender equality provisions but urges explicit recognition of occupational health risks faced by women in processing roles, beyond pay equity and social protections.  
GREEN_EFA recommends strengthening Article 349 TFEU protections by mandating periodic socio-environmental impact assessments for outermost regions, ensuring reforms do not exacerbate existing vulnerabilities.

ALDE partly accepts the issue's focus on small-scale fisheries but demands amendments to Article 349 TFEU provisions to explicitly ban EU-subsidized vessels from reflagging to non-EU registries, addressing systemic loopholes in fleet accountability.  
ALDE objects to the issue’s failure to mandate EU-equivalent sustainability standards for all imported fisheries products, creating market imbalances that contradict ALDE’s insistence on fair competition for European artisanal producers.  
ALDE requests revisions to Clause 22 on quota allocation, requiring member states – not just the EU – to prioritize small-scale fleets in catch share distributions, reflecting Chris Davies’ critique of national-level mismanagement.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s omission of binding mechanisms to ensure developing countries retain priority access to their coastal resources, inconsistent with ALDE’s development-focused trade principles articulated by Gesine Meissner.  
ALDE supports gender equality measures but requires stricter enforcement language in Clause 17 to penalize member states failing to implement equal pay verification systems for women in auxiliary fishing roles.

SD supports the issue’s focus on decentralized, regionally tailored fisheries management, aligning with their advocacy for flexible policies co-developed with coastal stakeholders to protect small-scale fleets.  
SD advises strengthening data collection through mandatory smartphone-based reporting systems for recreational fishing, as highlighted in debates, to enhance transparency and combat illegal salmon fishing.  
SD endorses the proposed European sustainability label for artisanal products, emphasizing its potential to address market imbalances and secure fair pricing for low-impact fisheries.  
SD calls for explicit recognition of shark finning loopholes in enforcement protocols, urging stricter harbor inspections to align with the issue’s ecological goals.  
SD highlights the need to accelerate EMFF funding allocations for gender equality programs, ensuring equal pay and occupational safeguards for women constituting 85% of small-scale fisheries labor.

ECR supports the issue’s emphasis on decentralized fisheries management and rejection of transferable fishing concessions, aligning with their advocacy for regionally tailored, sustainable practices.  
ECR advises strengthening the issue’s sustainability criteria by explicitly banning shark finning and mandating "fins naturally attached" policies to eradicate wasteful practices.  
ECR proposes amending import standards to exclude non-EU fisheries engaging in shark finning, ensuring coherence with the issue’s sustainability label objectives.  
ECR highlights the need to modernize enforcement mechanisms, such as real-time monitoring of catches, to complement the issue’s data collection priorities.

GUE/NGL supports the issue’s emphasis on decentralized, regionally tailored fisheries management and its rejection of mandatory transferable fishing concessions, aligning with their opposition to market-driven mechanisms that marginalize small-scale fleets.  
GUE/NGL advises strengthening the external dimension of the CFP by mandating that fisheries agreements with third countries prioritize building local capacity for sustainable resource management, rather than perpetuating extractive practices.  
GUE/NGL proposes amending the issue to explicitly ban destructive practices like shark finning, citing the ecological necessity to protect endangered species and uphold biodiversity commitments.  
GUE/NGL highlights the need for stricter monitoring frameworks in fisheries partnerships, including enforceable corrective measures when objectives are unmet, to ensure equitable outcomes for developing nations.  
GUE/NGL stresses that gender equality measures must be expanded to address informal labor precarity, particularly for women in processing roles, beyond the current focus on pay equity and occupational disease recognition.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of small-scale and artisanal fishing, which constitutes 80% of EU fishing activity through vessels under 15 meters, in sustaining coastal communities, employment, and food security, while emphasizing its vulnerability to economic shocks, aging fleets, and insufficient data. It called for decentralized, regionally tailored fisheries management, rejecting mandatory transferable fishing concessions (TFCs) as economically discriminatory and ecologically ineffective, and advocated flexible, science-based policies co-developed with local stakeholders. The resolution stressed the need to modernize fleets for safety and sustainability, enhance gender equality by recognizing women’s contributions (85% of whom work in small-scale fisheries) through equal pay, social protections, and occupational disease recognition, and address market imbalances by creating a European sustainability label for artisanal products. It urged increased EMFF funding for coastal communities, prioritizing projects with socio-environmental benefits, compensating fishermen during biological rest periods, and improving data collection on fish stocks, socio-economic impacts, and gender disparities. Additionally, it highlighted the importance of protecting outermost regions under Article 349 TFEU, promoting sustainable aquaculture, and ensuring imported fisheries meet EU sustainability standards.

title: Specific actions in the Common Fisheries Policy for developing the role of women: REPORT on specific actions in the Common Fisheries Policy for developing the role of women
background: Women's labor in EU fisheries and aquaculture sectors faced persistent underrecognition despite comprising over 100,000 workers, with systemic barriers to legal status, social protections, and gender-disaggregated data. The Parliament will discuss integrating gender equality measures into the Common Fisheries Policy to address occupational disparities and enhance women's socioeconomic inclusion in maritime industries.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue's mandate for gender-disaggregated data collection and social protections, which aligns perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to equitable labor conditions and maritime community welfare.  
EPP approves leveraging EMFF funds for women's microcredit access but proposes extending support to include transitional assistance for small-scale fishermen in Croatia facing age-based restrictions, enhancing regional cohesion.  
EPP applauds the directive compliance measures for family fishing businesses as effectively advancing EPP's priority of formalizing informal economic contributions through legal status recognition.  
EPP endorses the call for women's participation in advisory councils, noting this matches EPP's 2023 manifesto pledge to double female representation in sectoral governance by 2027.  
EPP highlights the need to operationalize shellfish gatherers' injury compensation through EMFF-backed insurance schemes, reinforcing EPP's focus on preventive healthcare in hazardous occupations.

ALDE supports the issue’s recognition of women’s indispensable roles in fisheries and aquaculture, aligning with ALDE’s commitment to gender equality in maritime economies.  
ALDE advises enhancing EMFF accessibility by amending Article 8 to earmark 30% of microcredit allocations for women-led processing cooperatives and portside childcare services.  
ALDE endorses harmonized gender-disaggregated data collection, proposing standardized EU metrics for informal labor in shellfish gathering and seasonal employment.  
ALDE stresses the urgency of enforcing Directive 2010/41/EU to ensure maternity leave parity for women in family-run fishing enterprises.  
ALDE recommends revising Clause 12 to mandate 40% female participation in fisheries advisory councils by 2027, ensuring decision-making inclusivity.

SD supports the issue’s emphasis on gender-disaggregated data collection and advises amending Article 5 to mandate annual reporting by Member States on progress in closing wage gaps.  
SD highlights the need to expand EMFF funding clauses to prioritize grants for women-led aquaculture cooperatives, citing successful models in Sardinia and Sicily as benchmarks.  
SD suggests strengthening Annex II to include subsidies for ergonomic equipment tailored to shellfish gatherers, addressing joint injury risks highlighted in the debate.  
SD urges harmonizing Directive 2010/41/EU compliance by adding explicit pension portability guarantees for women in cross-border family fishing enterprises.  
SD advises integrating gender equality training into fisheries advisory council protocols, proposing a 30% participation quota for women in Article 7 decision-making roles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the underrecognition and invisibility of women’s contributions to the fisheries and aquaculture sectors, noting that over 100,000 women work in these industries across the EU, with 4% in extractive roles, 30% in aquaculture (notably shellfish gathering), and 60% in processing. It highlighted their harsh working conditions, lack of legal and social protections, wage disparities, and exclusion from decision-making roles. The resolution urged the Commission and Member States to improve gender-disaggregated data collection, harmonize statistical indicators, and recognize women’s labor through legal status, social benefits (including pensions, maternity leave, and occupational disease coverage for joint/back injuries), and equal pay. It called for leveraging the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) to support women’s initiatives, microcredit access, and emergency compensation during fishing bans, while promoting women’s participation in advisory councils and ensuring compliance with Directive 2010/41/EU to grant self-employed-equivalent rights to women in family fishing businesses. The resolution also emphasized integrating gender equality into fisheries agreements, research programs, and the Common Fisheries Policy, stressing the need to address poverty, violence against women, and sustainable development in fishing-dependent regions.

title: Use of alien and locally absent species in aquaculture: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 708/2007 concerning the use of alien and locally absent species in aquaculture
background: The European Commission proposed amending a 2007 regulation on aquaculture species use, following research on environmental risks and administrative burdens. The Parliament will discuss balancing aquaculture industry needs with biodiversity protection through updated rules for alien and locally absent species in closed facilities.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly advocates the issue's strict adherence to Lisbon Treaty provisions ensuring Parliament's co-decision authority in fisheries management, perfectly aligning with their institutional reform priorities.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's socioeconomic sustainability focus through Amendment 7's protection of artisanal fisheries in Area 8C, enhancing coastal community preservation while maintaining single-stock integrity.  
EPP fully supports the streamlined aquaculture regulations as exemplifying their commitment to reducing administrative burdens while maintaining rigorous environmental safeguards for alien species.  
EPP endorses the harvest control rule mechanism as scientifically robust implementation of maximum sustainable yield principles, consistent with their 2023 manifesto on ecosystem-based fisheries governance.  
EPP aligns completely with the urgency to resolve institutional deadlocks through trilateral dialogue, prioritizing functional application of Article 43(2) TFEU over procedural delays in stock management.

EFD supports the issue's recognition of regional aquaculture challenges but urges explicit safeguards against EU-wide ecological mismanagement  
EFD advises amending Article 3 to require socioeconomic impact assessments specific to national fishing industries  
EFD highlights concerns about persistent EU structural failures in fisheries policy, citing GBP 11.1 billion annual losses as evidence for subsidiarity principles  
EFD endorses transparency mechanisms but proposes mandatory consultation with coastal communities before species introductions  
EFD recommends benchmarking aquaculture rules against third-country practices to prevent competitive disadvantages

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the issue’s emphasis on precautionary management of fish stocks, aligning with their commitment to ecosystem-based fisheries policies.  
GREEN_EFA endorses maintaining exploitation rates below 0.3 for anchovy stocks as proposed by the Commission, ensuring safety margins for sustainable yield.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on scientific advice in management plans, particularly the rejection of splitting horse mackerel quotas contrary to expert recommendations.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing discard reduction measures by revising cod recovery regulations to address unintended consequences while maintaining stock recovery goals.  
GREEN_EFA approves the issue’s alignment with Treaty of Lisbon principles, reinforcing Parliament’s role in safeguarding outermost regions’ socioeconomic sustainability.

ALDE strongly promotes the issue’s alignment with the precautionary principle in fisheries management, emphasizing sustainable practices that protect both marine ecosystems and long-term industry viability.  
ALDE endorses the call for intensified data collection and research to inform aquaculture policies, recognizing this as foundational to balancing ecological and economic priorities.  
ALDE proposes enhancing provisions for reducing bureaucratic barriers to innovation in aquaculture, ensuring regulatory frameworks prioritize adaptive, science-based solutions.  
ALDE applauds the focus on socioeconomic sustainability for outermost regions, aligning with their commitment to tailored policies that address unique regional challenges.  
ALDE highlights the importance of exploring market mechanisms for fishery by-catches to minimize waste while maintaining strict sustainability criteria.

SD firmly approves the issue's Treaty of Lisbon alignment, particularly Article 294(3) codecision protocols, as critical to reinforcing Parliament's role in outermost region fisheries governance.  
SD perfectly aligns with the mandate for science-based quota systems, echoing S&D's insistence on ICES data driving anchovy stock management to prevent irreversible ecological damage.  
SD supports the issue's socioeconomic prioritization, mirroring calls to differentiate coastal horse mackerel fishing practices that preserve day-boat fleets' cultural viability.  
SD endorses permanent high-grading prohibitions in Baltic waters, recognizing these as foundational to the no-discards policy advocated in S&D's CFP reform agenda.  
SD advocates rigorous aquaculture facility standards to prevent ecosystem contamination, aligning with biodiversity safeguards emphasized in closed-system definitions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to adapt fisheries management measures in the EU’s outermost regions under Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), aligning with the Commission’s 2009 proposal (COM(2009)0541) to address specific regional challenges. It emphasized legal coherence with the Treaty of Lisbon, particularly Articles 43(2) and 294(3) TFEU, and endorsed the Committee on Fisheries’ report (A7‑0184/2010) to ensure tailored policies for these regions. The resolution adopted Parliament’s first-reading position, urging the Commission to maintain transparency by reconsulting Parliament if proposing substantial amendments. It instructed its President to communicate Parliament’s stance to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing interinstitutional cooperation while prioritizing the socioeconomic sustainability of fisheries in outermost areas.

title: Scheme of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down a Scheme of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries
background: The 1978 North-East Atlantic Fisheries Convention established multilateral cooperation through NAFO, amended in 2007-2008 to modernize management structures and align with international standards. The EU, as a contracting party, required ratification to comply with updated obligations. The Parliament will discuss ratifying the amended convention and implementing updated control measures under the agreement.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly accepts the issue's immediate transposition of NEAFC control schemes into EU law, perfectly aligning with its commitment to eradicate illegal fishing through harmonized enforcement.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the report's clarification of delegated acts under Article 290 TFEU, ensuring institutional balance while maintaining Parliament’s legislative oversight over fisheries management.  
EPP firmly accepts the ban on non-ratified frozen fish landings, strengthening traceability measures to protect coastal communities from unfair competition and dubious imports.  
EPP perfectly supports the issue’s emphasis on sustainable resource exploitation, recognizing its critical role in preserving fish stocks for future generations as outlined in CFP objectives.  
EPP firmly accepts leveraging aquaculture development opportunities alongside robust controls, advancing both economic resilience in fishing regions and long-term food security goals.

GREEN_EFA completely advocates the issue's alignment with urgent measures to combat IUU fishing, particularly its emphasis on cross-RFMO cooperation and port state controls that perfectly mirror their 2023 ocean governance priorities.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s implementation of NEAFC-accepted monitoring technologies, recognizing this as critical for achieving the 30% marine protection targets outlined in the European Green Deal.  
GREEN_EFA proposes accelerating the adoption timeline for dispute issue mechanisms to match modern IUU operators’ adaptability, enhancing the existing framework without modifying its core principles.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports the integration of scientific advice into enforcement protocols, noting this resolves longstanding concerns about CFP management raised in coastal communities like Scotland’s mackerel fisheries.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s implicit push for a global fishing vessel register through its high-sea surveillance provisions, a policy cornerstone since their 2019 “Transparent Seas” initiative.

ALDE absolutely accepts the issue’s alignment with modernized regional fisheries governance, particularly the streamlined dispute settlement mechanisms that reinforce multilateral cooperation.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the emphasis on sustainable stock management, recognizing its critical role in preserving both ecological balance and long-term EU fishing interests under the Lisbon Treaty framework.  
ALDE strongly agrees the institutional continuity achieved through procedural harmonization, which enhances Parliament’s role in fulfilling NAFO’s conservation objectives.  
ALDE proposes strengthening provisions related to the ongoing mackerel stock dispute by explicitly linking issue efforts to the Convention’s sustainability mandates, ensuring no repetition of past overfishing errors.  
ALDE commends the integration of binding environmental safeguards into enforcement protocols, reflecting the party’s commitment to science-based resource management in multilateral agreements.

SD firmly advocates the enhanced port state control measures and anti-illegal fishing provisions, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to sustainable fisheries governance in international waters.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's procedural framework for swift NEAFC decision transposition, emphasizing the critical need for efficient codecision to prevent implementation delays.  
The issue effectively advances SD's priority of combating unregulated fishing by mandating traceability of frozen catches and reinforcing regional organizations' enforcement capacities.  
SD firmly advocates integrating socio-economic considerations into stock management decisions, ensuring balanced sustainability as championed in SD's coastal community protection agenda.  
This aligns perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to multilateral cooperation, as demonstrated by advocating expanded regional fisheries authority over migratory species management.

ECR strongly accepts the issue's emphasis on comprehensive fisheries inspections across all EU waters, aligning with ECR's commitment to equitable resource management.  
ECR proposes enhancing quota distribution transparency by mandating standardized reporting protocols to address inconsistencies in Member State catch documentation.  
ECR approves the institutional alignment under the Lisbon Treaty framework, which effectively advances accountability in multilateral fisheries governance.  
ECR recommends strengthening the Fisheries Control Agency's oversight mechanisms to ensure inspection reports maintain objective regional impact assessments.

GUE_NGL strongly advocates the issue's framework for multilateral fisheries control, aligning with their commitment to sustainable resource management and combating illegal fishing.  
GUE_NGL applauds the enhanced monitoring requirements as a critical advancement in ensuring transparency and accountability within regional fisheries organisations.

GUE_NGL emphasizes the necessity of revising cofinancing rates under the Common Fisheries Policy to exceed 50%, ensuring Member States receive adequate financial support for monitoring obligations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal (COM(2009)0151) related to interinstitutional decision-making procedures following the Treaty of Lisbon’s entry into force, referencing Article 37 of the EC Treaty, Article 294(3) and Article 43(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and the Commission’s Communication (COM(2009)0665). The Parliament also instructed its President to transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, while considering inputs such as the European Economic and Social Committee’s March 2010 opinion and the Committee on Fisheries’ report (A7-0260/2010). The resolution emphasized procedural continuity and institutional alignment under the Lisbon Treaty framework.

title: EU-Liberia sustainable fisheries partnership agreement: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia and the Implementation Protocol thereto
background: The EU and Liberia signed a 2015 Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement to govern access for EU vessels, promote sectoral development, and combat illegal fishing, amid Liberia's post-Ebola economic challenges and coastal resource management needs. The Parliament will discuss concluding the agreement and its protocol on fisheries resource access and sectoral policy cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally sanctions the agreement's integration of access fees with sectoral development funding, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to mutually beneficial EU-Africa cooperation.  
EPP highlights the protocol's emphasis on scientific research capacity as a critical advancement in sustainable resource management, mirroring EPP's manifesto priorities for evidence-based fisheries governance.  
EPP applauds the establishment of a regional network of tuna agreements as strategically coherent with EPP's advocacy for multilateral solutions to migratory species conservation.  
EPP recognizes the rigorous monitoring provisions for EU vessels as exemplifying global leadership in ethical fishing practices, reinforcing EPP's standards for extraterritorial accountability.  
EPP underscores the alignment between Liberia’s national fisheries policy and the agreement’s capacity-building measures, effectively advancing EPP’s long-term vision for African coastal resilience.

EFDD conditionally sanctions the agreement but demands binding clauses in Article 5 to ensure 95% of sectoral funds directly reach artisanal fishers' cooperatives rather than government channels.  
EFDD requests revisions to reduce the 6,500-tonne EU catch limit by 40% to prevent resource depletion conflicting with Liberia's food security goals under SDG 2.  
EFDD highlights the agreement's failure to address neo-colonial exploitation patterns, fundamentally againsting with their manifesto commitment against EU external fishing fleets in developing nations' waters.  
EFDD requires amended surveillance provisions (Section 7.2) mandating real-time EU vessel tracking data sharing with Liberian coastal communities to combat illegal fishing allegations.  
EFDD insists on Brexit-era sovereignty principles being applied, demanding explicit clauses allowing unilateral suspension of EU access if local catch monitoring shows stock decline beyond ICCAT thresholds.

ENF strongly advocates the agreement's sustainable fishing framework, which aligns perfectly with their commitment to balancing ecological responsibility with European maritime interests.  
ENF approves the tiered financial model as effectively advancing bilateral development priorities, mirroring successful EU-Mauritania partnership structures they previously endorsed.  
ENF proposes enhancing local economic benefits by formalizing crew recruitment quotas for Liberian nationals, building on the 60% employment standard achieved in other agreements.  
ENF highlights the protocol’s alignment with international governance standards as critical to preventing illegal fishing – a longstanding ENF policy focus.  
ENF commends the emphasis on scientific cooperation, viewing this as essential for maintaining fish stocks while securing EU fleet access rights.

GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the agreement’s transparency framework, particularly Liberia’s commitment to publish all fishing contracts, which aligns perfectly with GREEN_EFA’s longstanding commitment to open governance and equitable resource management.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the alignment with the Mauritania-EU agreement model, recognizing it as a benchmark for elevating global fisheries standards and pressuring non-EU fleets to adopt sustainable practices.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the critical exclusion of certain species (e.g., bläckfisk) from foreign fleets to prioritize local needs, a principle that must be rigorously upheld to protect coastal communities.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing Article 4 to mandate third-party verification of published contract data, ensuring completeness and reliability without opposing the transparency mechanism.  
GREEN_EFA approves the financial allocations for Liberia’s fisheries development, which effectively advance priorities like scientific research and anti-illegal fishing efforts, reinforcing bilateral sustainability goals.

ALDE strongly promotes the exclusion of private fishing authorizations under the agreement, ensuring alignment with EU common fisheries policy and enhanced combat against illegal fishing, reflecting Liberia’s recent progress in this area.  
ALDE applauds the structured financial contributions to Liberia’s fisheries sector, particularly the allocations for scientific research and artisanal fisheries, which directly advance their commitment to sustainable development and bilateral cooperation.  
ALDE strongly endorses the transparency mechanisms requiring regular updates from the European Commission to Parliament, reinforcing their longstanding priority of institutional accountability in international agreements.  
ALDE approves the emphasis on sustainable fishing practices and local community development, which aligns perfectly with their manifesto goals for environmentally responsible partnerships and global fisheries governance.  
ALDE highlights the importance of rigorous monitoring to ensure funds effectively reach Liberia’s fishing communities, proposing enhanced joint evaluation frameworks as an opportunity to strengthen implementation without opposing the agreement’s core objectives.

SD completely approves the agreement's integration of transparency mechanisms and sustainable fishing quotas, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to global marine resource governance.  
SD completely approves the structured financial contributions to Liberia’s fisheries sector, effectively advancing SD’s priority of combating illegal fishing while strengthening local scientific capacity.  
SD completely approves the protocol’s alignment with Liberia’s national development goals, demonstrating SD’s dedication to ethical partnerships that prioritize post-conflict economic recovery.  
SD completely approves the emphasis on artisanal fisheries support and food security enhancements, ensuring EU-Liberia cooperation directly benefits local communities as mandated by SD principles.  
SD completely approves the rigorous compliance with international labor and environmental standards, reinforcing SD’s vision of sustainable development through equitable bilateral agreements.

ECR supports the agreement’s emphasis on combating illegal fishing and sustainable resource management but advises amending the protocol to explicitly prohibit shark finning by EU vessels, mandating full retention and utilization of sharks caught to align with EU regulations.  
ECR recommends strengthening labor rights safeguards within Liberia’s fisheries sector through targeted funding allocations, citing broader regional concerns like Mauritania’s human rights violations as justification for rigorous ethical oversight.  
ECR endorses the scientific cooperation framework but urges stricter monitoring mechanisms to ensure compliance with shark conservation measures during tuna fishing operations.  
ECR advises revising the implementation protocol to include periodic audits of labor conditions in Liberia’s fisheries, ensuring alignment with international labor standards.  
ECR supports the financial contributions for sector development but proposes earmarking funds for community-led initiatives to empower artisanal fishers and prevent marginalization.

GUE_NGL partially advocates the agreement but insists on amending Article 5 to mandate consultation with Liberian artisanal fishers, citing parallels to Ireland’s pre-EEC exclusion from fisheries policymaking.  
GUE_NGL requests revisions to Annex 2, demanding transparent third-party audits of access fee calculations to ensure proportionality between EU vessel quotas and financial contributions.  
GUE_NGL calls for inserting binding language in Section 7 to allocate 40% of sectoral support directly to coastal communities for surveillance infrastructure protecting small-scale fisheries from industrial competition.  
GUE_NGL opposes the inclusion of super-trawlers under permitted vessel categories, urging deletion of Clause 3.2(b) to prevent ecosystem damage consistent with their stance against destructive industrial fishing practices.  
GUE_NGL warns the current text risks replicating Ireland’s post-accession resource depletion and demands Article 9 include safeguards guaranteeing Liberian authorities’ unilateral suspension rights for stock protection.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval for the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement and Protocol between the EU and Liberia, which establishes a five-year framework for EU vessels to access Liberian waters with a reference tonnage of 6,500 tonnes annually. Financial contributions include access fees set at €357,500 for the first year, €325,000 annually for the second to fourth years, and €292,500 for the fifth year, alongside equivalent annual allocations (€357,500; €325,000; €292,500) to support Liberia’s fisheries sector development. This funding aims to strengthen scientific research, artisanal fisheries, monitoring, control, surveillance, and combat illegal fishing, aligning with Liberia’s national fisheries policy objectives. The resolution emphasizes the agreement’s role in promoting sustainable fishing practices and bilateral cooperation while ensuring compliance with international fisheries governance standards.

title: EU-Mauritania fisheries partnership agreement: fishing opportunities and financial contribution: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania for a period of four years
background: The European Union and Mauritania have a longstanding fisheries partnership, with prior agreements governing access to Mauritanian waters under the EU’s Common Fisheries Policy. The Parliament will discuss renewing the four-year protocol defining fishing rights and financial contributions to ensure sustainable resource management.

stances.stance:
EPP totally sanctions the issue's alignment with sustainable fisheries management, perfectly reflecting EPP's commitment to balancing EU fleet interests with ecological preservation.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the emphasis on scientific stock assessments, urging accelerated completion of demersal species studies to expand fishing opportunities responsibly.  
EPP fully supports channeling €16.5 million annually to Mauritanian maritime development, reinforcing EPP's principle that sectoral aid must directly empower local economies.  
EPP proposes strengthening future protocols by revisiting cephalopod fleet inclusion through enhanced scientific cooperation with Mauritanian authorities.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's contrast between EU sustainability standards and third-country fleets, endorsing exclusive access for EU vessels to prevent overexploitation by less-regulated operators.

EFDD slightly accepts the protocol but demands binding clauses preventing EU vessels from displacing local Mauritanian small-scale fisheries, citing risks of neo-colonial resource exploitation.  
EFDD requests revisions to Articles governing financial transparency, requiring direct auditing of sectoral support funds by coastal community representatives rather than central authorities.  
EFDD opposes the agreement’s failure to substantively transfer fishing capacity-building to Mauritanian operators, inconsistent with EFDD’s sovereignty principles.  
EFDD insists on amending environmental safeguards to mandate real-time bycatch monitoring with penalties for EU vessels exceeding limits.  
EFDD asserts the issue totally condemns with national control over maritime zones, advocating Brexit to end EU-imposed fishing quotas.

ENF strongly upholds the sustainable fishing quotas and reduced EU financial contributions as prudent adjustments balancing ecological responsibility with budgetary discipline  
ENF approves the reinforced 60% Mauritanian crew requirement, aligning with its emphasis on fostering local employment and skills transfer in partner nations  
ENF endorses the elevated supplementary aid to Mauritania, recognizing this as a strategic investment in regional stability and counterterrorism cooperation  
ENF highlights the agreement’s role in revitalizing EU-Mauritania Francophone ties, consistent with its prioritization of cultural-linguistic alliances in foreign policy  
ENF proposes formalizing third-party audits for sectoral support funds to enhance transparency while maintaining the issue’s core financial commitments

GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the issue's emphasis on transparency in fisheries agreements, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to combatting illegal fishing through open publication of all access treaties.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the Mauritanian protocol’s exclusion of squid fisheries to prioritize local food security, urging formal codification of such exemptions in future agreements.  
GREEN_EFA approves the €16.5 million annual sectoral support as effectively advancing sustainable development priorities, particularly scientific stock assessments and small-scale fisheries capacity.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening Annex II to mandate real-time public reporting of catch data, ensuring published information meets reliability standards comparable to Liberia’s model.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s alignment with their manifesto by requiring third-country fleets like China’s to adopt equivalent sustainability measures, thereby leveling ecological standards globally.

ALDE entirely agrees the Protocol’s exclusion of private bilateral fishing authorizations, ensuring alignment with the EU Common Fisheries Policy and enhancing the fight against illegal, unreported, and unregulated fishing, which perfectly aligns with ALDE’s commitment to multilateral governance and sustainable resource management.  
ALDE applauds the earmarked €16.5 million annual allocation for Mauritania’s fisheries sector, recognizing its direct alignment with ALDE’s priority of fostering equitable bilateral cooperation that prioritizes local socio-economic development and maritime policy modernization.  
ALDE highlights the Protocol’s transparency mechanisms and parliamentary oversight provisions as critical to ensuring accountability, which effectively advances ALDE’s longstanding advocacy for institutional accountability and participatory policymaking in international agreements.  
ALDE commends the strict adherence to scientific recommendations and sustainable catch limits, resonating with ALDE’s environmental stewardship principles and dedication to combating overexploitation of marine ecosystems through science-driven frameworks.  
ALDE stresses the imperative of rigorous human rights and labor standard enforcement for fisheries workers, reflecting ALDE’s unwavering commitment to embedding ethical practices and social justice within EU external agreements.

SD firmly supports the transparency framework mandating publication of all Mauritanian fishing agreements with third countries, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to preventing resource overexploitation and protecting local artisanal fisheries.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s integration of human rights clauses and labor standards, reflecting SD’s core principle of ethical fisheries partnerships that prioritize worker protections.  
SD highlights the protocol’s sectoral support allocation (€16.5 million annually) as a model for ensuring EU funds directly bolster Mauritania’s maritime policies and coastal communities, advancing SD’s development-focused agenda.  
SD applauds the strict adherence to scientific catch limits and bycatch monitoring requirements, which operationalize SD’s long-standing advocacy for ecosystem-based fisheries management.  
SD acknowledges concerns about cephalopod fleet exclusion as an opportunity for future technical dialogue while maintaining full endorsement of the agreement’s sustainability safeguards.

ECR supports the sustainable fishing framework and scientific oversight provisions, aligning with conservation priorities in the issue.  
ECR advises strengthening Article 6 to explicitly prohibit shark finning across all EU-Mauritanian fishing activities, mandating real-time monitoring by the joint committee.  
ECR stresses rigorous enforcement of human rights conditionality, requiring quarterly audits on Mauritania’s eradication of forced labor practices as a precondition for continued sectoral funding.  
ECR proposes expanding transparency protocols to include public reporting on bycatch mitigation efforts, ensuring alignment with EU environmental standards.
